etymologies: Old English; earliest use found in Writ of Edward the Confessor, Westminster. From blood + wite. Compare post-classical Latin blodwita, blodewita

definitions: A fine payable for the offence of shedding blood; (also) a legal action for this offence; (occasionally) †the offence itself (obsolete). Also: the right of levying this fine; (occasionally) †the privilege of exemption from it (obsolete).

notes.text: To be distinguished from fight-wite, a fine for the related offence of fighting.

definitions: Generally. A penalty for murder, especially (usually in form bloodwit) in Islamic jurisprudence.
